description.text: This shape is a world record holder you need 20 tiles before it will tile the plane periodically (10 up to symmetry). It fits together in an amazing variety of ways but can easily block itself. Making it a fun puzzle. The tiles were found by a massive computer search by Joseph Myers. Look for this and other puzzling shapes at: http://www.srcf.ucam.org/~jsm28/tiling/ The idea to make physical tiles was originally from Chaim Goodman-Strauss: http://www.mathbun.com
Cut out of acrylic/card/wood/stone using your favourite cutter, laser water-jet, craft etc. Cut file set up for A4 sheet.

comments.text: Hi! Thanks for this great idea. The file has a small error--not all the tiles are exactly the same shape. I think after the tiling was done, the whole thing got squashed a bit along one axis. With the material, size, and kerf I used, it turns out that the tiles don't fit in some orientations (well, not without applying a lot of force).
comments.author: eshira

comments.text: The stuff that can be made with this is amazing. Somebody needs to sell this idea to tile makers and brick makers. Can you imagine what a brick house or a tiled patio would look like using these patterns as paving tiles! No more plain brick homes. Every wall would be different. ABSOLUTELY AMAZING! I'm going to start cutting tiles ASAP for my back yard.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Personally I do like a nice brick pattern, so I am not going to follow you all the way. I do agree that Myers Tiles patio would be awesome. I look forward to seeing pictures!
comments.author: Guest

comments.text: The blue and red colors makes me think that this could also be a two-player game, like Hex.
comments.author: failrate

comments.text: What a great idea. A general tiling game. You alternate placing tiles.  The winner is the last player to move. There's probably a winning strategy even in a tilable case like this but coule be fun...
comments.author: failrate

This idea originates from August 2015, when I started designing/printing plastics. I saw my kids trying to build a roof for a Kapla house, but it'd always fall apart. As their frustration grew, I started thinking how wonderful it'd be if they would have plastic clips to hold the wooden pieces together. To my surprise, no such thing existed, so I started drawing in sketchup and did a few test prints.
Because a few other parents were enthusiastic as well, I decided to put the files and the design on Thingiverse. I hope you'll have fun with it as well.

Printer Brand:

Up!

Printer:

Up Mini

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

any

Infill:

none really needed

Notes: If you'd print the parts sideways, no support would be needed, but this depends on your printer and how well it can print horizontal planes on top of vertical ones.
example prints of stl files various clips to show the idea Building a roof with the CouplaClips The same roof from a different angle

Drawing in SketchUp Drawing these clips is pretty straightforward: first I modelled a wooden piece and then I drew the roof clips around them. For the other couplings I drew a basic shape (the CouplaClip-100) and moved/copied/merged that shape into the new ones. In case you'd need new shapes, this is probably the fastest way to create them.
One word of caution though: Sketchup is sometimes know to do some funny things when merge two shapes. The best way to check this is either with the SolidInspector plugin in SketchUp or with NetFabb (if needed, the free version of NetFabb allows you to do some basic repairs which usually do the trick) Modifying the Sketchup drawing and part names When I started this series of clips, the first two were the roof clips: a lower and an upper part. Then I thought of the various couplings for walls, floors etc. To distinguish them from each other, I thought of a 'system' to name the parts without having to open them. The idea is simple: you have three axis and each digit reprents the number of connections on that axis. So, for instance if you'd need a piece with two connections in x and y direction, look for a CouplaClip220, ...221 or ...222. If anyone wants to add more parts, I'd appreciate it if you'd continue this :-)

title: Desk Lamp Mount - Swing Arm Manifier w/ flourescent lamp

description.text:
The base broke on my desk lamp. It was an outlet type base. The lamp is pretty heavy so there is a lot of pressure on the base. I tried the base only to what was left of the post, and that was not strong enough. So I made the tapered post with a thick pad and used a 1/4-20 3.5" bolt to pull it all together. The bolt is not strong enough and will bend. Make sure to tighten the assembly before testing. I was able to use the post as a nut of sorts and focus the compression onto the baseplate/pad assembly, this allows it to swing easier. I used a fender washer where the plastic parts meet.  
I included OpenSCAD file of the post. I did the base plate while experimenting with 123D Design. Both files are included for your use.

title: Dough Roller and Docker
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I got the idea thinking how I haven't tried making a good thin crust pizza at home yet. I remember at the pizza place I worked at long ago they used a roller to form fit the dough to a pan and then the docker to puncture and assure a nice clean rise/look. Open to ideas on the design, I think it should be as simple as print 2 of whatever roller type you want and glue together. Then print a handle and fit one end, and gently push the other end into place. I scaled my first print of it (pictured) down a little to test, and so far I can confirm the model needs a couple changes. The spikes are longer on one side than the other (not sure how I did that) and I need to add another 2 planes of spikes at 45 degree angles since it seems to catch a little if not spinning freely. That said, it works as-is and I'll find time to update it at some point. Enjoy, and let me know what you think.

author: Skulbl4k4

description.text:
A nice wall hook for my folding step-stool, a Cosco 11-115-PBLC1.  Leaning the stool on the wall worked for a while but I didn't like accidentally kicking it over, or when it fell over on its own and made a big clang.
Designed in 123D Design.

I wanted something strong, so I configured my slicer with the following:
  • PLA
  • 3 shells
  • 30% infill
  • add solid diaphragm every 20 layers (Simply3D setting)
  • 0.2mm layers
  • add automatic support structures
    • The overhanging lip turned out a little messy, even with the support, but the stepstool hides that part.
I used two number 10 wood screws, 3/4" long, to mount into the side of my kitchen cupboard.

description.text:
The scalable multi-purpose clip.
Fast to attach and remove and can be done so one handed. Note:
This is a small object with close clearances so a relatively well tuned printer will be needed.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

20%

Notes: Two perimeters/shells work well but if you find that the claw tips snap off of you let the claws snap shut then increase the perimeter count.

What files to use: Print a A and B side, if you find the fit to be too tight use the loose versions.
If you plan to scale them up use the Tight version.
The Tight version worked well for 150% and 200% scale, bigger then that and it might be a bit loose but should still function unless you go way too big. Assembly: Fit the hole over the post with the claws in the fully open position. You will find that the end of the clip with a hole/post has a small point that will catch a little during assembly, this is intended, a little force/wiggle should get it to snap in.
With the claw still fully open wrap the rubber band around the little hooks, try to insure that each loop of the rubber band has about the same tension in it or it wil bunch up as the claw is closed.

author: rubio24000

description.text: I built this to accommodate FAKE E3d V6 dual heads,that i purchased from china ... I used a pen soldering gun to weld on the top. I had to drill the holes, and sand out the bearing slides, as I printed with supports.  I threaded the belt through the ports and secured by running a screw through with the belt. I printed in abs, It worked well, but there was a lot of cooling from the free flow of the 40mm stock fans, printed nylon fine. I built this for my ctc/Bizer Flashforge clone.. Warning one of the first parts I ever made! lol  I built this in ONSHAPE.COM

Bowden coupling spacers, designed to fit the E3D embedded and threaded couplings. It can probably be resized to fit other connectors. With the threaded connectors, instead of using one of these, I prefer to preload it by screwing in the coupling with the PTFE tube sticking out slightly (with filament loaded). Printer:
-- Eustathios Filaments: (full list can be found on thrinter)
-- Yasin Yellow PETG
-- eSun Transparent Red PETG

Hallo,
ich habe ein Heizungsgehäuse erstellt, um den Bauraum des CTC 3D-Druckers zu beheizen.
Das Beheizen des Bauraumes macht Sinn, wenn man größere Objekte aus ABS drucken möchte.
ABS hat die Eigenschaft Spannungsrisse zu bilden. Man kann diese durch eine gleichbleibende
Temperatur im Bauraum reduzieren bzw. komplett vermeiden.
Dieses Gehäuse ist von hinten an den CTC geschraubt, daher müssen die Rollenhalter von dort weg.
Habe meine Rollen schon von Anfang an auf den Drucker gestellt,somit hatte sich diese Möglichkeit als beste erwiesen.
Man muss den Drucker aber komplett geschlossen haben. Habe hier auch ein Gehäuse dafür erstellt.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1052609
Da ABS eine Betttemperatur von 100-120Grad braucht, empfiehlt es sich den Drucker mit preheat auf Temperatur (Bett und Nozzle) zu bringen und dabei die Heizung mit einzuschalten, dann brauch die Heizung nicht so lange.
Außerdem sind alle Teile im Bauraum dann auch auf Temperatur und es gibt dann auch keine Probleme mit dem Druck selber wegen der Wärmeausdehnung.
Habe diese Heizung schon ein Weile Einsatz und die funktioniert ohne Probleme.
Das runde Gehäuse habe ich mit 45 Grad Bauraumtemperatur gedruckt.
Die Heizung schafft aber auch 60 Grad und mehr. Das Heizungsgehäuse ist aus 5mm Leimholzplatten gelasert.
Es müssen insgesamt 12 Teile gelasert werden.
1 x Deckel oben
1 x Deckel unten
1 x Rückwand
1 x Platte innen
1 x Links Heizungsplatte
1 x Rechts Lüfterplatte
2 x rechts und links außen
2 x rechts und links innen
2 x InnenPlatte Schräge Dazu habe ich noch ein Sicherungskasten für eine Schmelzsicherung und Blenden
für den Innenraum erstellt. Achtung: Ich bin kein Elektriker, das Nachbauen und die Verwendung der hier gelisteten Teile
geschieht auf eigene Verantwortung.
Für entstandene Schäden hafte ich nicht.
Man sollte schon etwas Erfahrung mit Elektrik haben,da hier mit 230V gearbeitet wird.
Dazu würde ich eine Webcam empfehlen,wenn der Drucker z.B. im Keller steht, um diesen beobachten zu können. Hier die Links für die zugekauften Teile. Temperaturregler: http://www.ebay.de/itm/30A-220V-Digital-Thermostat-Temperatur-Regler-Thermoelement-40-120-mit-Sensor-/191655132807?hash=item2c9f893e87:g:KV4AAOSw9N1Vwyde
oder
http://de.aliexpress.com/item/30A-220V-Digital-Temperature-Controller-Thermocouple-Digital-LCD-Display-Temperature-Tester-with-Sensor/32426569015.html Diesen in die Front einbauen, dafür muss das Netzteil des Druckers um einen Abstand der Befestigungsschrauben versetzt werden.
Der Regler schaltet nach erreichen der eingestellten Temperatur die Heizung ab und 2 Grad unter der Temperatur wieder ein.
Den Fühler davon in Höhe des Lüfters an einer Innnenwand befestigen. PTC Keramik Heizung 220V 500Watt
http://de.aliexpress.com/item/PTC-ceramic-air-heater-500W-220V-Insulated/486754270.html Es gibt auch eine mit 700Watt.Diese passt auch. Falls diese verwendet wird müssen die Befestigungsbohrungen versetzt und die quadratische
Öffnung vergrößert werden. Dann ist ein schnelleres aufheizen möglich. Mir reicht allerdings 500Watt.
http://de.aliexpress.com/item/PTC-ceramic-air-heater-700W-220V-Insulated-140-76mm/486751900.html Das gute an diesen Heizungen ist,das diese ein Thermoelement mit verbaut haben.
Damit heizt die Heizung bis max. 200Grad Oberflächentemperatur auf und schaltet dann beim erreichen der Temperatur ab.
Somit ist da kein Überhitzen möglich, falls der Temperaturregler nicht abschaltet. Feinsicherungshalter für den Sicherungskasten:
http://www.ebay.de/itm/2-Stck-ESKA-Sicherungshalter-fur-Feinsicherungen-auf-Platinen-/222004663687?hash=item33b0825587:g:s6cAAOxy4dNS5AX~
Den Sicherungskasten drucken und eine Ader beim Zusammenbauen mit dem Sicherungshalter verlöten. Lüfter 92mmx92mmx25mm 24V:
http://www.ebay.de/itm/EE92252B1-A99-Axial-Luefter-92x92x25mm-24V-87-4m-h-34dBA-von-Sunon-/111377356183? Lüftergummi ist kein muss, aber gut gegen Vibrationsgeräusche:
http://www.ebay.de/itm/Silikon-Dichtung-weicher-Montage-Rahmen-fuer-Luefter92x92mm-schwarz-/311259760218? Wobei ich den Lüfter mit 12V betreibe damit der Luftstrom nicht so hoch ist.
Da empfiehlt sich so ein einstellbares Netzteil, so kann man auch nur mit 9V oder sogar weniger arbeiten:
http://www.ebay.de/itm/Goobay-Universal-Netzteil-Ladegerat-NTS-300-einstellbar-3V-12V-300mA-Adapter-USB-/191376643345?hash=item2c8eefd511:g:4nkAAOSw7PBTmEnF Dc-Buchse für das Netzteil:
http://www.ebay.de/itm/DC-Einbaubuchse-fur-Hohlstecker-2-1x5-5mm-DC-Buchse-einbau-Kupplung-Steckdose-/271356348957?var=&hash=item3f2e194a1d:m:m2yJWPgwsxkGwUsnmqoH8xw Verbindungsklemmen, diese gibts auch im Baumarkt und da würde ich diese auch kaufen,da man dort auch Kabel und anderes direkt mitnehmen kann.
Achtung nur diese Klemmen mit Klemmhebel benutzen die man auch wieder öffnen kann!
Die anderen sind Steckklemmen und für Drähte gedacht. Die mit Klemmhebel klemmen Kabel.
http://www.ebay.de/itm/Wago-Klemme-Verbindungsklemme-Dosenklemme-Leuchtenklemme-Hebelklemme-Klemmen-/331761846361?var=&hash=item4d3e8c0859:m:m9Q3L4r6lW6kBA_R_CMiEyA Netzschalter für die Heizung:
http://www.ebay.de/itm/Universal-Netzschalter-Schalter-Wippschalter-1-pol-250V-10A-Schwarz-/400495569782?hash=item5d3f656b76:g:qqEAAOSwaA5Wipc2
Es kann natürlich auch ein anderer verwendet werden. Ich schalte mit dem Schalter nur die Heizung selber ein und aus.Das Netzteil für den Lüfter muss
ich noch separat einstecken. Dafür kann ich die Spannung und damit die Geschwindigkeit des
Lüfters steuern. Alternativ kann man sich auch so ein Trafo verbauen und damit den Lüfter versorgen.
Dann brauch man die DC-Buchse auch nicht mehr.
Das kann man dann auch über die Klemmen mit dem Schalter verbinden und schaltet somit beides gleichzeitig ein.
http://www.ebay.de/itm/DC-12V-6W-60W-SMD-Strip-LED-Trafo-Treiber-Transformator-Driver-G4-MR16-Lampe-/151348663432?var=&hash=item233d155488:m:mWrCO9WLqmIxJ8u6OpaA2VA Holzschrauben 2,5x15mm Kreuzschlitz, Leim und schwarze Farbe in Sprühdose aus Baumarkt.
Inbusschrauben M3x16 und Muttern M3. Viel Erfolg. Hier eine gute Adresse um dieses Schneiden zu lassen, habe mein Gehäuse auch da lasern lassen. http://plexilaser.de/

author: Laur3nt

description.text:
Sun visor for a Garmin Montana 650 GPS (Note that the visor covers the camera).
The visor clamps around the GPS providing shade for the display in bright sunlight making it easier to see.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes: The bolt holes on the clamps need to have a drill of the same size passed through them to remove a thin infill that makes printing without supports possible. A brim on the print will stop any lifting or curling of the base while printing. I am getting excellent results printing on Kapton tape with these settings: Temperatures:
  • Extruder 220c layer 1
  • Extruder 200c layer 2 onwards
  • Bed 85c layer 1
  • Bed 70c Layer 2 onwards
  • 10mm Brim
  • 0.2mm layers

Step 1 Remove brim (it should just snap off)
Clean up edges if necessary with a craft knife Step 2 Run a 4.5mm drill bit through the holes on in the clamp parts to remove the thin infill in the holes. This infill is deliberate it allows the parts to print without need ing any supports Step 3 Assemble the Visor around your GPS using:
  • 4x M4x30mm Socket head Cap screws
  • 4x M4 Nylock Nuts
    • Align the visor to the screen and then tighten the screws to clap the visor around the GPS.

description.text:
A friend at our makerspace made a little engraver with some dvd burners, following this Instructable http://www.instructables.com/id/Pocket-laser-engraver/ (working surface : a bit more than a business card) But I wanted to give it a nice structure (and maybe an enclosure later), this first version is even foldable :) More pics and progress on our wiki :
http://wiki.nybi.cc/index.php/Pocket_Laser_Engraver

The spacing between the little smooth rods in the salvaged DVD can vary (in our case it was approx. 47mm), so you may have to measure with a caliper what's yours and tweak the source file. Beside that, this version was made to be cut from 3mm material and assembled with some printed parts and M4 bolts (I had a bunch of M4x16, but a little shorter would be better). Unscrew needed parts and put everything on the structure (reuse the little bolts for the motor plate, or take M3 and file holes to fit).
Alternatively you can replace the 16 bolts and 8 printed parts that hold the smooth rods by 8 zip-tie. At the end you'll have an ultra-portable-laser-engraver perfect for small demos and little jobs :)

description.text:
This simple bed mount was designed to hold in place the print bed. The print bed used is a glass or mirror 4 millimeters thick and a common heat bed.
Note that this bed mount is thought to be used with a print bed being the same size as the heat bed. To hold securely the bed in place, you need to have two "back glass mounts" and at least one "glass mount" When printing, I is recommended orienting the pieces as shown in the slicer software image attached. (If you decide to print them and use them, please upload a photo and give me some feedback!! I'll be very thankful)

Geeetech pro X (prusa i3)

100%

Notes: Plastic to use: ABS, as it will be in touch with the print bed and you don't want them to melt.

The back bed holders are always in place. To lock them there, remove the heat bed and place the screws once again but this time including the bed holders. (Should have them as shown in picture. Now you can place and remove the front holders and remove the print bed whenever you want!

author: hal123

title: Customizable GoPro Action Camera 360 rig (with underwater case)

description.text:
This thing has not been tested, you are welcome to participate in proposing any improvements you see fit, and print-testing it (it is a big thing >150g).
It is clear I need some real dimensions of the GoPro waterproof casing, I would be glad If anyone can provide actual measurements.

This rig will enable you to record 360 videos with 6 (or more) action cameras. This is the only rig of it's kind (that I know of) published in Thingiverse, that allows you to do so with all the underwater cases. So, in theory, you could use it to record 360 videos underwater! You will need hex head screws instead of the gopro thumnutted screws as they will not fit. It is designed to be used either with a 1/4" nut (for standard photography tripods) or/and triple GoPro compatible connectors (for use with any standard GoPro accessory). You can configure the number of cameras: 6,7,8,9,... how many do you need? subtract 2 (top and bottom cameras) and set it as N and done. Make sure you set the MaxCamDim with care, measure the dimensions (in mm), use the maximum (this will typically be the width of the camera). Remember to add some spare space. Consider adjusting this parameter also if your camera connector is not centred. This extra space might also come handy for N>4, as the available height for the camera to fit within the rig will be reduced (Of course you can always set the cameras at an angle outside the rig). You can also render just the edges, so if you need a lot of cameras and your printer can not cope with the volume, you can still print all the Simple Edges (plus at least one Main Edge for top and bottom cameras) individually. I would recommend to friction weld it for best results, but you could also stick it with epoxy resin or cyanoacrylate glue. Code available at GitHub: https://github.com/amedranogil/360Rig

comments.text:
I know the issue with the rig. this won't stitch as the camera positioning is not correct.
The positions on sides are all vertical. thats not correct for VR. You need the positioning to be Horizontal (H) and vertical(V) alternate.
so it should be from side HVHV instead of HHHH that it is now. As for top and bottom, LHS, TOP, RHS config should be V, H, V or H,V,H looked up from any side.

comments.text: It is now fixed, variables were not being set correctly and as result there was no output.
comments.author: Luchino_1980

comments.text: Would mind explaining how you resolved this? I'm having the same problem and you're the only person I've found who's been able to fix it.
comments.author: amedrano

comments.text:
Hello,
My case was particularly dumb: there were some variables that where not being defined correctly for the customizer. These variables controlled the output models being generated. The thing is that locally openscad did not interpret these variables, it used the default value, and thus output was produced, but when the customizer runned the script, the variables took the values from the customizer setting (the comment part).
In the end the problem was a bit stupid (and partly due to poor documentation from the customizer app); value strings in the customizer options don't need to be within double quotes ("), unlike the value of openscad string. If you put the double quotes the customizer will include them as part of the string, thus when you compare these strings they will not match.
Find exactly what I am talking here. Notice the quotes for model variable, and also how the ifs were set in a way that if model did not have one of the expected values, no output would be produced.

title: 1970 AMC Ambassador SST Headlight Adjuster clip

description.text:
I couldn't find the exact headlight adjuster clips for my 1970 AMC Ambassador SST, and all of the existing clips were broken, being held together with zip ties.
I made these and so far they seem to be holding. I haven't tested driving at night for a while though, the heat may be too much for ABS. 
Hopefully someone may find this design useful. I drilled the holes manually after printing for greater structural integrity. By drilling the holes slightly too small, I found I could self-tap standard M6 bolts in.

Cans often leave annoying rust-rings on bathroom ceramics. The culprit in my particular case was a shaving-foam canister. This clip has saved me a lot of trouble. Check out this YouTuber's build and review of the ring! :) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FzyJQTmmqSw With a ferro-based canister, rust-rings need three more ingredients to form -
  • water,
  • time, and
  • contact.
    This minimalistic clip helps by
    • adding distance between the can and the ceramic (i.e. no physical contact)
    • adding slopes and drainage, so that water doesn't stagnate under the canister
    • adding ventilation-gaps so that any water that does get under shall evaporate easily
    • As an added bonus, it might make your canisters 'stackable' ;) I've used mine on a Gillette canister having base-OD of 57.6mm and cap-OD of 55.8mm. You can measure your particular canister and scale the model accordingly; the dimensions are pretty forgiving. For fine-tweaks (after printing the model), if needed, dip it in hot water (almost boiling) and let it mould to your particular canister. This method can enlarge as well as shrink the clip by a few %. On my canister, both the base and cap go on with a satisfying "click".

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Typ. 0.4mm nozzle; 0.3mm z-layers

Infill:

Heavy

Notes: The grippy-fingers (the five pointy things holding the canister) need good inter-layer-adhesion - otherwise they'll snap. I printed with ABS and also PLA and at a temperature slightly higher than normal to enhance inter-layer-adhesion. The water-vent arches (i.e. on the bottom-half) need support. The grippy-fingers do not.
The usual cleanup is needed after removing supports. Shrink or expand with hot water, if needed, to make an exact fit. (see above)
Measurement with calipers, followed by 3d-sketching in FreeCAD with basic geometric shapes, Boolean operations, and fillets.

I needed a mount for my Flysky FS-IA6 radio receiver to put on my Immersion Vortex 285 and couldn't find one that worked.  I used Questpact's Antenna Mount as inspiration and created my own in 123D Design.  The antenna on the receiver needed supports to mount and hold them at the proper angle and I wanted to be able to easily remove the receiver if necessary so I designed it so the antenna could be un-zipped from the mount.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.27

Infill:

10%

Notes: Printed in ABS at 4 shells to add strength and make sure thinner areas were solid, while keeping the weight as minimal as possible.

Instructions The receiver has two antenna that I wanted to mount at 90 deg. to each other. I used large zip ties to act as antenna support. Shrink wrap them to the antenna, adding a bit larger piece to cover the ends. Use double sided tape to mount the receiver in the mount and small zip ties to mount the antenna. Then, use double sided tape and zip ties to mount to your quad. I beefed up the antenna mount after my first version cracked upon a harder than usual landing (uhh, that's called a crash....) ;)

title: Cell phone microscope
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: It is a holder for a sample, a lens and a cell phone, which together act as a microscope. There are many set ups like this documented on the Internet, but I wanted to make a sturdy supporting structure. The lens has 7mm diameter and is taken from a cheap laser pointer. Sample is put between a reversal film slide holder, which keeps at least hair pieces well together. There is room for material that diffuses the light evenly behind the sample. I cut some from a diffuser of an old broken LCD monitor. The 3D model has 45 degress slope to attach a piece of mirror to, so it is possible to attach a light source horizontally to save a lot of space. Light source can be for example a LED flashlight. I used a 4 watts Ikea desktop light, which seems to be a minimum. Phone holder is for old iPhone 3G but the solidworks model can be adjusted for other cell phones and camera positions.

description.text: ring

title: Dial Indicator holder for Rostock Max

description.text: This will allow you to temporarily mount a Pittsburgh dial indicator from Harbor Freight onto the effector plate of the Rostock Max.  This can allow you to more precisely level and adjust horizontal radius than you can using a paper shim.

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

15%

Notes: I used 3 top & bottom layers and 3 perimeters to make the part pretty stiff.

How to use Slide the fixed sleeve of the dial indicator into the center hole of the printed piece. It should be very snug, as you don't want it to move. Install the assembly in place of your hot end using the three screws & standoffs with the display facing toward you. The stylus of the dial indicator should reach well below where the extruder normally is. That is OK. Use your software to tell your printer to move to Z height of 0 then carefully zero the dial indicator. This will be your zero point of reference from that point forward. You can now use your tower calibration routines, and horizontal radius adjustment process to fine-tune your printer. When everything looks close (don't worry about anything less than 0.05mm) remove the dial indicator and carefully reinstall your hot end. To double-check your work, preheat your bed & hot end, then use your software to move to a Z height of ~5mm. Then, use the front console to carefully dial down toward zero. If it needs a little Z adjustment at this point, that's OK. Use the console to do that, then you're ready to print. Z height adjustment should be the only thing you'll have to adjust unless you change other parts of the system, or the printer gets a hard bump.

title: Rostock max v2 dual spool holder

description.text:
This is the dual spool holder setup for Rostock Max v2. It works brilliant, and spins great with the 608zz bearings on a M8 threaded rod. Instructions:
We used 30% innfill for all of the items. Works great. Printed in PLA+ . Tolerances for where the bearings goes is tight. Needs to be knocked in. If you find it hard to measure where to drill the holes for the funnel, just print the funnel guide plate. To mount the base plate you need to unassamble the spool holder. Its a tight fit, bit it will go in there. The tight fit is needed to stop it from wiggeling. Use a M2 screw & nut to secure it on place. For the nut finishers, use some superglue and glue the nuts to the finishers. Accessories needed:
M8 threaded rod (1x cut to: 320mm)
M8 nuts (2x (lock-nuts if you have))
608zz bearings or simular sized ones. (4x , 2 on each roller)
M2x16mm screw and nut Print Qty:
1x off all the not listed files
2x Roller_v2.stl
2x nut_finisher_v2.stl
3x washer_for_bearing_clearance.stl This spool holder also works as a solo spool holder. You need a shorter M8 rod, 1x roller, 2x washer_for_bearing_clearance.stl. Funnel:
m3 shcs or simular m3 screws (4x)
m3 nuts (4x)

SeeMeCNC

Rostock MAX

No

No

30%-100%

Edmonia Lewis's Old Arrow Maker illustrates an excerpt from the Song of Hiawatha by Henry Wadsworth Longfellow, in which the character Minnehaha plaits "mats of flags and rushes" while her father makes "arrow-heads of jasper." They both look up to greet Hiawatha, whose presence is implied by the deer he brought as a token of marriage. Lewis often created sculptures of Native Americans, and possibly chose the character of Hiawatha because he was from the Ojibwa tribe, like her mother. The coming together of the Ojibwa and Dakota tribes may refer to Lewis's hopes for reconciliation between the North and South after the Civil War. In the story, Hiawatha later marries Minnehaha with the wish that ". . . old feuds might be forgotten/ And old wounds be healed forever."

description.text:
This terminal block was designed for use on the Roboroos (FRC Team 4537) robots. We use it for high current connection of motors to speed controllers for quick replacement.
Use 1/4"x1/2" Roofing bolts with square nuts. The nuts embed into recesses underneath the block. We used a 1/2"x 1.5" aluminium bar drilled to suit as the connector.
The lid is held down by an M3 bolt into a hex nut similarly embedded into the bottom of the block.

0.3mm layers

30% - 50% for strength

Notes: The lid prints well on its side with no support. Although there are hollows under the block, you can also print the block with no support as the nuts will compress the loose fibres underneath.

It's easy to turn a webcam into a simple microscope using a jewellers loupe. They can be had for less than 2 euros on the web.
This is an adapter I designed to fit my cheapo loupe. Not the highest quality, but enough to identify the colour bands on resistors.

Edit the parameters to suit your loupe.
Print it out and snap it onto your loupe. 
Fit webcam on to loupe and attach by hooking an elastic band over the hooks on the side.

A Quarter Acceptor that rejects penny's, nickles and dimes. If the coin inserted is smaller than a quarter it will fall into the coin return. A larger coin will not fit. If a Quarter is inserted it will slide down a shoot and block the IR light from hitting the IR detector causing a pulse to be sent to the microprocessor. Connect an IR LED and detector to send a pulse to your favorite microprocessor such as an Arduino or Raspberry Pi.
I will also be designing a coin box and vending device for this soon.

description.text: Moving somewhere else

Since the peices are quite small, I highly recommend using the raft feature.  This ship will be pretty big once assembled, so I advise low infill settings.  The following is my opinion on each peice.  
Cut 1 - Raft with supports.  Although some printers may pull off using no supports, but the little needles will not print without support.  
Cut 2 - Raft and supports.  This will probably be the toughest one to print.  
Cut 3 - Raft and support.  If you have good overhang capabilities, you might not need supports.  
Cut 4 - Raft and supports.  Same as Cut 3.  
Cut 5 - Raft and supports.  Supports are necessary.   
Cut 6 - Raft and supports.  Same as Cut 5.  
Cut 7 - Raft.  Supports are an option  
Cut 8 - Raft and supports

author: jshickman

description.text: THIS HAS BEEN REPLACED BY THE FOLLOWING: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1350845 The first of I'm sure many iterations of my case design for a Raspberry Pi Bramble (supercomputer). I am calling the individual PCBs a leaf because, well, they're part of the bramble (bush) of raspberries. My first chassis will have slots for 4 leaves and have provisions for power and network (a big issue with Pi Zeros). I wanted to get the leaf design down first and make it an easy setup for others. I just loaded 2 other STLs a few hours after creating the initial project.: These are my solution to my issue with building a proper Frame. The Rail Mount will hold the Pi Zero and has a larger footprint than the Frame. When you sandwich the Rail Mount between 2 frames, you will be left with a top and bottom rail to slot the Leaf in to the chassis. Print the Bramble Box file twice and you will have 2 leaf frames and the complete chassis frame ready to glue up into a box that should allow slot loading of the leaves. Thereafter just print the 3 laminates for each subsequent leaf. You will need and end stop so they don't slide out. UPDATE: 2/9/2016. I'm thinking Edge Connectors like PCI connectors on a motherboard can be used to make these an easy slotload. Also, I will be working on printing the case this week to check clearances. Those rails might not be wide enough. Also, I added an end stop on the slides. To make this strong I will use the PCB that will hold the edge connectors and simply glue it to the back side. UPDATE 2/9/2016 - I made an improvement to my leaf design. I have included a fence around the section with the ears which support the Pi Zero. Now you don't have to laminate the 3 layers (though I am still working out how to make the Pi sticky, as it were. UPDATE: 2/11/2016- first leaf printed okay. I changed the infill to 20% for the leaves. Might could shift the left side of the usb hole further over for sloppier clearance since I haven't got locator pins yet. Also need to consider the GPIO pins. For progress' sake, I'm leaving it for now. I have a timeline to follow. I'll print the second leaf and see if I have to change PLA spools before I tackle the rails (I guess they could be called branches since the leaves will ride on them)

title: FT Mini Arrow Power Pod (Fuselage Modified for 1500mah Battery)

description.text:
FT Mini Arrow Power Pod. This power pod is for 2204 2300kV motor for a fuselage modified to fit a 1500mah battery. This fits snug into the fuselage allowing a good friction fit. I also found it weighed 2g LESS than the original foam pod. 
I was having issues with the original power pod in that the motor was overheating. My guess was the motor was caught in the vortex of the blunt back and was not getting adequate air flow. THIS SOLVED THE OVERHEATING ISSUE. 
Mount/Pod has a channel for the wires. Interior cavity also aids in extending space for ESC. It does bring the COG back, but the 1500mah battery compensates for it. 
The pod fits into a fuselage cavity measuring 35mm x 28mm.

description.text: Update 8/5/2016: I think the problem I had with the ring's not fitting the mesh inserts was that the ABS I used shrinks a bit. If you can, print the lid at 102% to 105% of its original size, to avoid a jar lid that is too tight on the jar and/or does not fit the mesh inserts. I will see about uploading a 102% and a 105% oversized ring for anyone whose software does not allow scaling. Please let me know your results of any parts you attempt to use. Thanks! Hang on for now, don't print it. The ring fits the jars, but the Insert mentioned below does not fit through the ring. I'll have to adjust the ring. Sorry for any inconvenience. This is a Jar Ring for a wide mouth mason jar. It's a remix of AlexEnglish's Canning Jar Lid (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:19105). I uploaded the Wide Mouth version of his Lid to TinkerCad, and punched a 73mm hole through the center of the lid. This ring fits the default Mason Jar Sprouting Insert by schlem (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:97431). The outside dimension of the ridge on those inserts is about 72mm, thus the hole size indicated above. The issue for me is: Metal mason jar bands rust! I figured I'd just be able to find some plastic mason jar bands, but they just don't seem to be out there. The tops the vendors include with the mason jar sprouting kits tend to stick on the jars. So, hey, that's why we're into 3D printing, right? These won't work for canning, of course, and don't try it! They are intended for holding whichever kind of insert you want to hold on to the jar, where a metal band would be a problem, such as sprouting seeds. I tried this in ABS, and it works, but it feels like the band wants to break. Most likely these would work better in a more flexible filament. PETG is not really necessary because it is not in contact with the food, but it might have the correct physical properties nevertheless. Comment on this if you come up with something better, let me know.

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes: I assumed supports would be required because of the threads. I might try without them. I used Simplify3D and auto-generated the supports.

comments.text: My opinion is that the issue with the tightness is a result of the material itself shrinking.  I used ABS, which is known to shrink as it cools, so that a printed part can end up as much as 3% smaller than intended.  I printed a 20cm calibration cube and it's just about 19mm on a side, so that's about right.  I'd try scaling the model at 103% and see if it works.

title: Raspberry Pi 2-B+ Case w/RAMBo mount arms

description.text:
ACTUALLY remixed from (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:922740) which is a remix by the same designer of the one it wants me to indicate as a remix. Stupid Thingiverse - no cookie for you! The changes in my design are as follows:
  • The mounting arms have been modified to match the screw pattern for a RAMBo controller (95mm x 96mm). My intention was the mount it on the back side of the board using the same screws, but I imagine you could use some really long screws with some standoffs to mount it above the RAMBo.
  • The GPIO slot has been opened vs. the breakaway slot in the original since I need access to some of the pins.
  • Many of the edges have been rounded.
    • It uses the same screws as the one it's remixed from: (4) #4-24 x 1/4" pan head sheet metal screws, (4) #4-24 x 3/4" pan head sheet metal screws, and the mounts are sized appropriately for M3 screws.

I had a request to make the internal Pi mount screwless.  V2 is my first pass at that.  It's currently untested, so if you print it out before I do, please post a comment to let us know how it turned out.  It might be a few days before I can get to it.

I had a change in plans so was able to print out the V2 top and bottom of the case and mount it in my Prusa i3.  I wound up using some metric M3x20 machine screws since I didn't have any SAE #4x3/4" sheet metal screws.  It worked perfectly - the fit was very snug and the Pi isn't going anywhere.
Due to another request, I created a v3 based on the internally screwless v2 without the mounting arms.

T-MAX 2.0

author: kas2323

description.text:
"Please do not move while The Nozzle is engaging." The Nozzle is an enigma. It is also calibrating, so please do not move. First seen on The Venture Bros episode "The Invisible Hand Of Fate", it freaked Billy Quizboy right the heck out. And why stop with him. Don't you want to be freaked right the heck out too? Now you can! You too can have the soothing presence of The Nozzle in your own home, where it will do whatever it is The Nozzle does. For you and for your family. Glue or otherwise bond the Throat to the body. This will leave a slight join line, which is intentional as The Nozzle has a line around it's body. The Butt screws to the body. I did not add screw holes to the pylons inside the body so that you can use drill and use whatever size screws or bolts you wish. If you don't plan to add lighting, you could just fill the holes in the Butt and glue/bond it to the body. The hole in the butt is just a bit smaller than an 8mm threaded rod which, if covered in flexible tubing, could be bolted to a nice stand. Or perhaps you have a gooseneck lamp lying around that can be turned into a base for The Nozzle. The Nozzle is probably meant to be a shiny stainless steel (and changes shape during the scene, so I split the difference), but I painted mine a nice metallic nickel and it looks spiffy. The Eye goes in the top of the throat and if you print it hollow (in red or or clear and paint it red), you should be able to light it up nicely. Or you could drill holes in the back and add LEDs. Mine is screwed onto a flexible lamp whose neck is covered in flexible tubing which I painted the same color as my The Nozzle. (Note: That's my prototype in the picture with a piece of black chart tape around the middle, that was before I added the seam line.) "The Nozzle has completed calibration. Thank you." Links:
http://teamventure.org/vbwiki/The_Nozzle
http://www.adultswim.com/videos/the-venture-bros/the-nozzle/

A simple test piece I use to set filament temperatures. Uploaded to help a forum member solve an issue but it might be helpful to others as well. Print with a brim. The following general rules will help dial in the perfect temp. I am not sure where I found these instructions, kudos to the author. It may not be the end-all, but they have been helpful to me. I have added the bits in parentheses based on my own experiences.
  • If the model shrinks at the bottom thus lifting the corners up then the overall bed temp is too high.
  • If the bottom corners/edges peel up around the outside, the first layer bed temp is too low.
  • If layers separate overall extruder temp is too low or extrusion multiplier needs to be increased.
  • If the sides of the model has blobs, the extruder temp is too high. (also check for improper retraction settings.)
  • If the extrusions in the model have gaps, the extruder is too cold and/or print speed is too fast. (Also check for partially clogged extruder and moisture/dirt in filament.)

title: Western Digital My Passport Hard Drive Enclosure
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a collection of modular units that I created to hold several handy Western Digital MyPassport external hard drives. I created the designs to handle the four drives I have connected to a little server. They were slipping all over the place.
The drives are all slightly different sizes. This enclosure should hold most variations. It's made to work as a shelf, and units can be permanently attached to the left, right, top and bottom of each other. There's an STL file that is a cover. I also made a special cover that holds my Amazon USB hub to which the drives are attached. You can add stick-on feet to the bottom units, and pull the feet off if you add more units to the bottom.
Updated: 2016-02-09 Updated the Amazon Basics USB enclosure. Brought the brackets in closer to the device. I also included top supports. They aren't permanent. I made the stubs short and glued them. Maybe they should be clips. I'd love feedback on the various locking and slip brackets if you use this. Maybe I should include some cable management.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.30 mm

Infill:

10%

Notes: I printed this at low fidelity with diamond infill.

Assembly If you print multiple pieces, you can snap them together. Just line the parts up and push together. Make sure to snap both sides at the same time. There's a panel that goes across the back of the drive where the USB comes out after you slide it into the enclosure. Make sure to print a top piece.
This was created using Tinkercad. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/0gLXrZ33Xts

This is a desk lamp I designed in Fusion 360. http://a360.co/1SYqRtg
I wanted to see if I was still much slower in Fusion vs Soldiworks, Took me about an hour and a half to model up. So not so much. Though Fusion is way more awkward in reference geometry and surfaces. The lack of 3d sketches is no good either. I designed it around the parts I found in the lamp repair section. See if you can match up the parts in the photo to replicate it. You may have to adjust some of the dimensions in the model. The lamp screws down to the table with 1 3/4" #8 screws. The diffuser is made from copier paper. Pdf attached. It takes around 300g of plastic at 35% infil with 3shells and supports. Make sure to print the parts so that the grain runs parallel to the arms and not around the perimeter. 2x innie
2x outie

If your workspace is like mine you probably have one or more extension cords running over it. I created this holder to have something that will get the cords off the desktop but keep the plug end of the cord within arms reach. This holder slides onto the edge of the desk and provide a hook that will hold a cord with a 3-prong adapter (large), a single heavy duty cord or something else (single). It holds to the desk without any glue, screws, etc and can be attached/removed in a second. I have created stl files for each of the 3 types for both 1/2 inch and 3/4 inch thick desktops. If you need additional customization make and edit a copy of the model file for yourself on Onshape.com here: http://tinyurl.com/zv9yk6x

description.text: Titular character from The Snow Queen, by Hans Christian Andersen. This character was modeled for our sci-fantasy tabletop RPG, Wayfarer: Things Beyond Wonder and for Wayfarer Tactics. If you want to print a 28mm scale version, just scale it up by 166.6%. The files for a dual-extrusion version are included. We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested to help fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...) Enjoy!

title: Handle Spool and Tool Holder for Printrbot Simple Metal

description.text: This is a remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:387313, with a tool holder attached. There are no other good ways of mounting a tool holder on the Simple Metal that I could think of. I also decreased the size of the handle a little bit to accommodate spools with 33mm inner diameter, and increased the size of the mounting holes opposite the nut holes to allow use of an 8mm washer. There are two versions of the model, one with the holder flush with the top for easy printing, and the other with the holder 30 mm lower to reduce the total height when tools are sticking out the top. The latter version would require support material, however. See graphic and photo for tools accommodated. I really like the Vetus tweezers that came with my Felix printer and the metal ruler that comes with the Taz. I use the razor holder (Thing 34481) to remove parts from the print bed. The tweezer holder is derived from Satoer's model, which I couldn't find on Thingiverse.

Printer Brand:

Type A Machines

Printer:

2014 Series 1

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

200 micron

Infill:

50%

Notes: At 178 mm in one dimension this might be dicey printing on a Simple Metal, though I seem to recall being able to move it as far as 180 in X. I happen to have access to a variety of different printers, so this wasn't an issue for me. If there's interest, I could see about making mods to fit it onto the simple metal 150x150 print area. For the version requiring support material, I've included a Cura plugin that cuts off the support material at a fixed layer number (150 if printing @ 200 micron). Above that, everything should bridge OK. This print is quite susceptible to lifting at the ends and corners, so I recommend using a brim.
I used OpenSCAD to design this.  Code is available upon request; I didn't include it because it relies on importing files and using libraries, which could be confusing for beginners.

This stand is small and lightweight, but still strong enough to hold your macbook. If you have rubber spray, spray some to get more friction so that it can hold the macbook better. You can still plug the power cable and thunderbolt cable .

title: Star Trek Original Series - Hand Phaser Type I - Midgrade

description.text: A replica of the Phaser (Type I) prop from the original Star Trek series. This is the "midgrade" version (detailed enough to be seen in close-up, but no moving parts or electric components); a "hero" version is also in the works, and I plan to also make a Type II body into which these will fit. I've included bodies for both the original version from the early first season, and the Wah Ming Chang screen-friendlier redesign that was used throughout the rest of the series. For the early version, print "Midgrade P1 Body - Early Season One", "Midgrade P1 Thumbwheel", and "Midgrade P1 Emitter". For the later version, print "Midgrade P1 Body", "Midgrade P1 Thumbwheel", "Midgrade P1 Emitter", "Midgrade P1 Crispy", "Midgrade P1 Rail 1", and "Midgrade P1 Rail 2". There's also a "unibody" version of the latter, for those who absolutely hate printing multipart models, though it would make painting somewhat more tedious, and I would suggest using supports for the bottom of the thumbwheel (the bodies are intended to be printed vertically, with no supports). NEW: I've added, by request, a "Midgrade P1 Body - Hollow" for SLS printing services. This version passes the Shapeways checks for all the plastic options currently available. For the later version, you will also need an acrylic sealer such as Mod Podge, clear epoxy, an 8.5mm (1/3") length of 19mm (3/4") diameter clear acrylic rod for the gauge cover, and optionally a watch crown for the power indicator (I used an Esslinger jeweled dustproof watch crown refill, 4.5mm, Tap 10, Yellow w/ Blue) and an 8mm diameter by 3mm high (5/16" diameter by 3/32" high) cylindrical neodymium magnet for a "trigger" which doubles as a means of mounting the phaser on a ferrous or magnetic surface for display.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm layers

Infill:

25%

Notes: I printed all parts without supports or brims, except for the "crispy" (the rectangular part with a diamond pattern). On my printer, that part prints the cleanest when vertical, so I added a 15-line brim around it to keep it from tipping over. I also printed the main bodies on blue tape just for extra security, since they're tall and have a relatively small footprint.

1. Finish Parts For the bodies, I used Smooth-On XTC-3D, then sanded away any imperfections that remained using progressively finer grits (120, 220, 320, 600, 800, 1000, 1500, 2000). For the other parts, I sanded them using the same progression of sandpapers. The "crispy" (diamond-pattern metal plate) and the ridges of the thumbwheel were sanded only lightly, so as not to wear away the pattern too much. The XTC-3D was too good, and completely filled in the grooves used to indicate where the removable cover would be on the hero prop. I deepened the grooves on the model, but the photos show the original version. 2. Prime I used "Alclad II Grey Primer and Microfiller" on all parts. 3. Paint To get a nice smooth surface, I recommend using an airbrush. For the bodies, I used Vallejo paints (Black for the early version, German Grey for the later version), then after those had dried, gave them a coat of Alclad Klear Kote Light Sheen. For the metallic bits, I covered them first with Alclad II Gloss Black, then painted with Alclad II Polished Brass (for the emitter) and Alclad II Airframe Aluminum (everything else). I also painted the "screw" underneath, using Model Masters Silver paint and a small brush. Note on colors: for the early phaser, solid black is the appropriate color choice; later on, the color varied from medium-dark grey to black. (Note that the latter image is one of the lower-grade props with a sharp-cornered "crispy" and the rails just painted on.) 4. Glue together Using the clear epoxy (or your adhesive of choice), glue the thumbwheel into the rectangular depression on the top of the phaser, and the emitter onto the front, in the hemispherical space provided under the front detail. For the later version of the phaser, also glue the rails into the slots on the sides and the "crispy" at the front of the rectangular depression on top. 5. Gauges Print out the file "TOS Phaser I Gauges.png" at 600dpi. Coat both sides of the printout with Mod Podge (or similar acrylic sealer) and allow to dry. Cut out either one "1" square and one "10" square (for the early version of the phaser) or one of the graduated gauges. For the earlier phaser, use the clear epoxy (or your adhesive of choice) to affix the "1" label to the front square on the right side of the phaser body, and the "10" label to the rear square (see pictures for reference). For the later phaser, cut an 8.5mm (1/3") segment from the 19mm (3/4") rod. Then cut that almost in half (2mm off of center). Polish all cut edges of the smaller piece using successively finer sandpapers (as detailed in finishing step 1). Use clear epoxy to affix the graduated gauge to the flat rectangular edge of the gauge cover. Once that has dried, use clear epoxy to affix the gauge to the top of the phaser body, opposite the thumbwheel. 6. Power Indicator (optional) For a power indicator on the later version of the phaser, I used an an Esslinger jeweled dustproof watch crown refill (4.5mm, Tap 10, Yellow w/ Blue). I didn't have any drill bits the exact size I needed, so I drilled with the next smallest size down and used a small round file to enlarge the hole until the crown would sit flat on the phaser top. Place the hole between the thumbwheel and the gauge, just a millimeter or so rear of center. This feature didn't appear on all phasers, so it is an optional step. Color choice is also up to the user (of the two phasers shown in "Assignment: Earth", one had a blue crown and the other had a red one.) 7. "Trigger" (optional) Some phasers had a bright silver "button" on the underside. It's about the perfect size and shape for a cylindrical neodymium magnet 8mm diameter by 3mm high (5/16" diameter by 3/32" high), which can be used to affix the phaser to a ferrous or magnetic surface for display. Use clear epoxy to glue the magnet into the circular depression on the bottom of the phaser.

Modeled in Blender using reference photos from "The Making of Star Trek" (which very helpfully included a ruler for scale along with the top, bottom, and side views of the prop), and numerous HD screencaps from trekcore.com.

The body of the bench mount was designed in two parts mostly because it was too long for my PrintrBot Play. But also to work around printing supports. By printing the parts vertically there is no need for supports. Once printed the parts can be glued together. One other part is necessary, an adaptor to replace the threaded cover. The adaptor was designed by Nikolai Zoller: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1232949 I originally thought I would work the adaptor into my project but decided that trying to thread the Dremel on to the mount would be next to impossible. So, instead, the adaptor is threaded on to the Dremel and then the tool slides snuggly into the opening in the mount. I designed screw holes for fastening the mount to your bench or a board and a slot in the base to accommodate a hook-and-loop strap or zip tie.

The Delta PSU panel is a plxyglass lasercut panel to fit the USB type-B port, the power connector and a power switch.
The panel is designed to be mounted in a properlyKossel K250 delta model.

More Nuts and bolts on github. Itty bitty mighty bolts that hold together even with medium grade printers. Various sizes and print orientation to strengthen the print and resist shearing! Rescalable and more varieties to be added later. Super! All bolts have a slight taper to ensure torque, even with hard plastics. Mighty = horizontal prints for shear strength.
